div.p: I wrote you a note on my arrival the day after I left you. I was but 34 hours on my passage. The Boat was waiting at Cairo when the train arrived and as soon as the passengers could get on board shoved off so I had no time to see the Hubbards. I found business brisk and Athearn had worked but he had nicely kept up and very glad to see me. I am glad to say my cold is very much better I got a bottle of Iceynis Expectorant and it has nearly cured me the last two nights I have slept without coughing and only a bad spell early in the morning to clear my throat

and head. I think in a couple of days I shall be well The expectorant has morphine in it and of course keeps me scrating and sleepless. I got down in time to have my room at the office fixed up and slept in it and eat at a Restaurant. I have not yet been to see the Holmans as the work has been hard and tires me much so that I lie down as soon as it is over but expect to go today - Strawberrys are ripe but I have eaten none as yet as I have not got my taste back everything tastes alike. I have no idea as yet how long the Treasury regulations will last there are to be some changes but whether they will affect me or not I can not say. if I could get something to do where you could be with me I would not wait but resign
but I think I had better hold on for the present hoping you are all well I send much love
